Promoting & Preventing Evolution & Feeding The Localizing Foods
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 3 Archive (PS2): Items, Accessories, Foods: Promoting & Preventing Evolution & Feeding The Localizing Foods
By Lao on Wednesday, October 10, 2001 - 01:50 pm:

I found out two very interesting things today with respect to monster evolution.

First, if you've been feeding your monster a localizing food, but don't want it to evolve, take it to another area for its "growing up" phase. I had a dragon/? today that had been fed 6 mushrooms, and each time I let the evolution happen in Morx, he evolved into a /Morx. Whenever I moved him to grow up in another area (I tried all 4), he did not change from /?. So, if you want to feed your monster localizing foods because of their preference/nutrition, you can feel free as long as you move your monster out of the region during its growth spurt.

Second, evolution is not a hit or miss proposition. The same dragon, for its second growth spurt (it was now a dragon/morx), had been fed localizing food in Goat. I fed him 6 shellfish over 11 months. When he didn't evolve, I was surprised, but not dismayed--after all, this has happened to me before with a Gitan. I've gotten into the habit, though, of replaying the growth spurt multiple times to achieve the best combination of altered characteristics and dispositions. As I was replaying the growth for the third time, I decided to rest him into his growth instead of training, as I had been doing because that's what his training cycle called for. Suddenly, he evolved into a /Goat. My first thought was that the rest had triggered the evolution, but as I repeated the growth additional times, I discovered that he could evolve off of either a train or a rest, and that the odds across about 30 replays were very close to 50%. So, evolution is not a 100% determined process. There is some randomness involved. If your monster hasn't evolved when you think it should, or if it evolves when you think it shouldn't, try reloading. It may change the outcome.

Added info by Lisa Shock:
I was raising a dummy monster for my Battle Sense experiment, and had been checking various foods with it for yet another project. (Trying to get two projects done together.) Anyway, I had a Zan/Morx, and raised it only in Takrama. It was sent to hibernate for the week before each venture, while my other monster was out & venturing. The Zan was frozen a total of 5 times, and only lived in Takrama, and it evolved into the Takrama sub at the first growth spurt. So, going to town, and hibernating do not affect evolution.
